org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

div1.p: STATE OF WASHINGTON COUNTY OF SPOKANE ))) SS.

JOSEPH PLASTINO, Being first duly sworn, on oath says: He is, and for more than twenty-five years last past has been, a resident of the city of Spokane, Washington; that he is forty- six years of age, is the owner and proprietor of the Plastino Hotel in said city of Spokane; that he is a brother of Sam Plastino, against whom an order and warrant of deportation was issued on March 13, 1912, by Daniel J. Keefe, Commissioner General, Department of Commerce and Labor, Bureau of Immigration and Naturalization; that at all times on and after and prior to the 7th day of February, 1912, the relations between the said Sam Plastino and affiant were of a cordial and brotherly nature and character: that while affiant was sorely grieved and distressed over the prosecution and conviction of the said Sam Plastino in the case of the United states of America vs. Sam Plastino, affiant at no time suffered any change in his brotherly feelings toward the said Sam Plastino, and never withdrew from him such advice, aid, and comfort as were within his power to give; that affiant has read the propounded transcript of testi- money said to have been given by affiant at Spokane, Washington, on February 7, 1912, in the matter of the arrest of Sam Plastino before Thomas M. Fisher, Examining Inspector; that the said Thomas M. Fisher did not then and there, or at any time or place, propound to affiant the following questions, or any questions of similar nature or import:
Q. BY INSPECTOR FISHER. (To Joe Plastino, brother of Sam Plastino)

"Your brother, Sam Plastino, has been given a hearing to show his right to be, or remain, in the United States. He states that he wanted an attorney to represent him, provided you will furnish the same?"
That affiant did not then, or at any time, give the following answer, or any answer of similar nature or import:
"I am through with him for good; I will have nothing to do with hiring an attorney for him."

That the said T. M. Fisher did not inform affiant that deporta- tion proceedings were pending against the said Sam Plastino; that the subject of the employment of counsel for the said Sam Plastino in said matter, or in any matter or proceeding of any kind and character, was not then, or at any other time, mentioned to affiant in any form by the said T. M. Fisher; that said pretended answer did not represent the at- titude or feeling of affiant toward said Sam Plastino; that had affiant been informed that the said Sam Plastino requested, required, or de- sired an attorney to represent him in said matter, he would have procured counsel for that purpose.

That the only questions propounded to affiant by said T. M. Fisher, or any other person, in connection with said matter, related to the residence and citizenship of the said Sam Plastino and Michele Plas- tino, his father.
Joseph Plastino SUBSCRIBED AND SWORN TO Before me this 28th day of July, 1916.
LeRoy B. Hay Notary Public for the state of Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.
